title: U.K. Home Prices Grow at Slowest Rate in Six Years
text:
U.K. home prices inched up 1.1% in September compared to a year ago, the slowest annual growth in over six years, according to the Halifax Price Index on Monday.



The average British home sold for £232,574 (US$286,318) last month, a slight 0.4% decline from the previous month, according to Halifax, a major mortgage lender. The monthly report is one of the country’s longest-running market indices.

The sluggish price growth “remains in keeping with the predominantly flat trend we’ve seen in recent months,” said Russell Galley, managing director of Halifax.



September marked the slowest annual home appreciation since April 2013, Mr. Galley said.



For months, sales prices have broadly withered in the face of mounting political and economic uncertainty surrounding Brexit, with a few confounding exceptions.



For instance, mortgage approvals, a weathervane of market health, have remained robust, according to the latest figures from industry body UK Finance. Likewise, “affordability measures—such as wage growth and interest rates—still look favorable,” Mr. Galley said.



Marc von Grundherr, director at London-based real estate agency Benham & Reeves, said even the 1.1% annual growth in home values is impressive given the fraught political environment.

“The fact that the year-on-year numbers are still positive, quite honestly defies the gravity that the current political fracas should otherwise be dictating,” Mr. von Grundherr said, adding of a post-Brexit bounce, “We live in hope.”
